channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2023 The New York Times Company

item.title: Ukraine’s Allies Promise Weapons for Spring Counteroffensive
item.description: Ukraine and Russia are both running low on ammunition, and both are scrambling to replenish their stocks and gain a competitive edge.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora, Eric Schmitt, Valerie Hopkins and Ivan Nechepurenko
item.media:description: A Ukrainian soldier injured by shrapnel on the front line in the Donetsk region of eastern Ukraine, arriving at a stabilization point on Wednesday.

item.title: Garbage Piles Up in Protest Against France’s Pension Change
item.description: A bill raising the retirement age for most workers by two years, to 64, could become law this week despite widespread protests, including a strike by garbage workers in Paris and elsewhere.
item.dc:creator: Catherine Porter
item.media:description: Garbage piled up uncollected in Paris on Monday.

item.title: French Protesters Rally in Last Angry Push Before Pension Bill Vote
item.description: Many believe the legislation to raise the retirement age to 64 from 62 will pass Parliament, and they are looking beyond the vote to fight on.
item.dc:creator: Constant Méheut
item.media:description: Demonstrators in Lille, France, were among the hundreds of thousands who on Wednesday protested the government’s plan to raise the retirement age.

item.title: Retrial Ordered for Americans Convicted in Italian Officer’s Killing
item.description: The case of the two men, Finnegan Elder and Gabriel Natale Hjorth, who were both sentenced to more than two decades in prison, will now be sent to a new appeals court.
item.dc:creator: Elisabetta Povoledo
item.media:description: Gabriel Natale Hjorth, left, and Finnegan Elder during a hearing in Rome in April 2021.

item.title: After 12 Years, Japan Welcomes a South Korean Leader to Tokyo
item.description: The visit, the first of its kind in 12 years, is the latest sign of a diplomatic thaw. North Korea launched a missile hours before the countries’ leaders were to meet.
item.dc:creator: Motoko Rich and Choe Sang-Hun

item.title: Israeli Government Rejects President’s Judicial Compromise
item.description: President Isaac Herzog presented an outline he had hoped would calm the country and avert a constitutional crisis, but Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu immediately rejected the framework.
item.dc:creator: Isabel Kershner
item.media:description: President Isaac Herzog of Israel in November. On Wednesday, he made an impassioned speech on the government’s proposed judicial overhaul and raised the specter of civil war.

item.title: Israel Says It Killed a Bomber Who Probably Entered From Lebanon
item.description: Officials said that the man was behind a roadside blast in northern Israel, most likely after having crossed the border secretly, in a rare incident along the frontier.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley, Ronen Bergman and Isabel Kershner
item.media:description: Israeli forces on the border with Lebanon in January. Tensions on the Israeli-Lebanese border had been kept in relative check over the past decade.

item.title: Why the Black Sea Is a Flashpoint Between Russia and the West
item.description: It has long been a theater of competition between Russia and the West, a dynamic supercharged by the Ukraine war.
item.dc:creator: Ben Hubbard and Gulsin Harman
item.media:description: A Russian Navy ship entering the Black Sea through the Bosphorus strait in February 2022, before the Russian invasion of Ukraine.

item.title: A Hungarian Town Seethes Over a Giant Chinese Battery Plant
item.description: A $7.8 billion factory planned by a Chinese company in eastern Hungary has become divisive even within the party of Prime Minister Viktor Orban, who championed it.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Higgins
item.media:credit: Akos Stiller for The New York Times
item.media:description: The site of the future CATL battery factory near Debrecen, Hungary, this month. The project has angered even members of the ruling Fidesz party.

item.title: Blinken Calls for ‘Accountability’ on War Crimes in Ethiopia
item.description: Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken walked a careful line during a visit to Ethiopia as the Biden administration reassesses relations with the prime minister, Abiy Ahmed.
item.dc:creator: Michael Crowley and Declan Walsh
item.media:description: Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken arriving in Addis Ababa, Ethiopia, on Tuesday.

item.title: Teachers Join Wave of Public Service Strikes as U.K. Unveils Budget
item.description: A two-day strike by educators in England coincided with walkouts by doctors and transit staff. And it began on the day that the government detailed its new budget.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia
item.media:description: Teachers in England went on a two-day strike on Wednesday, joining in work stoppages by health care and transport workers, who have organized strikes of their own this week.

item.title: Cyclone Freddy Leaves Nearly 200 Dead in Malawi
item.description: The record-breaking storm barreled across southeastern Africa into landlocked Malawi, where rescue workers searched for survivors as rain kept falling.
item.dc:creator: Golden Matonga and Lynsey Chutel
item.media:description: Heavy rains caused by Cyclone Freddy cratered a road in Malawi that had connected the cities of Blantyre and Lilongwe.

item.title: UK Budget Offers More Free Child Care as Work Incentive
item.description: In a major policy speech, Jeremy Hunt, the chancellor of the Exchequer, offered plans to promote greater work force participation, including more free child care.
item.dc:creator: Eshe Nelson
item.media:credit: Sam Bush for The New York Times
item.media:description: St. Paul’s Cathedral in London. Britain’s economy is struggling with double-digit inflation, rising interest rates and widespread labor strikes.

item.title: Pentagon Chief Says He Spoke With Russia Over Drone Incident
item.dc:creator: Helene Cooper and Eric Schmitt
item.media:description: Defense Secretary Lloyd J. Austin III, center, with Gen. Mark A. Milley, the chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, and Celeste Wallander, an assistant secretary of defense, participating in a virtual meeting of the Ukraine Defense Contact Group from the Pentagon on Wednesday.

item.title: 6 Cities on 5 Continents That Are Reimagining Urban Life
item.description: What we can learn from creative city initiatives, from Sydney to Paris.
item.dc:creator: Jenna Schnuer
item.media:credit: Esteban Vanegas for The New York Times
item.media:description: Beginning in 2004, a system of gondola lifts were installed in Medellín, Colombia, which significantly reduced commute times and cost for people in rural mountain towns.

item.title: Protests in Peru: How Police Used Lethal Force Against Demonstrators
item.description: A New York Times investigation found that the country’s police and military fired lethal ammunition at unarmed civilians during protests in December and January.
item.dc:creator: Brent McDonald, Ainara Tiefenthäler and James Surdam
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: Ukraine Burns Through Ammunition in Bakhmut, Risking Future Fights
item.description: The military is using thousands of artillery shells a day as it tries to hold the eastern city, which could jeopardize a planned springtime campaign.
item.dc:creator: Thomas Gibbons-Neff, Lara Jakes and Eric Schmitt
item.media:description: Ukraine’s use of ammunition as it tries to hold Bakhmut is so intense that the Pentagon raised concerns with Kyiv, two U.S. officials said.

item.title: France Holds Its Breath Over Tense Pension Vote After Large Protests
item.description: French Senators approved President Emmanuel Macron’s proposal to raise the retirement age for most workers by two years, to 64. The outcome of a vote in the lower house is far more uncertain.
item.dc:creator: Aurelien Breeden
item.media:description: Demonstrators turned out in Nantes on Wednesday on the eighth day of strikes and protests against the government’s effort to raise the retirement age.

item.title: Two Acquittals, One 18-Month Sentence in Indonesia Soccer Disaster
item.description: The defendants, all police officers, were charged with criminal negligence in connection with the October stampede that killed 135 people.
item.dc:creator: Sui-Lee Wee and Dera Menra Sijabat
item.media:description: Police officers fired dozens of rounds of tear gas in a soccer stadium in Malang, Indonesia, on Oct. 1, an investigation found. The stampede that followed left 135 people dead.

item.title: Your Thursday Briefing
item.description: Here’s what you need to know.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: 近年来，瑞士信贷遭受了一次又一次的打击。

item.title: TikTok Pushed by U.S. to Resolve National Security Concerns
item.description: The demand hardens the White House’s stance toward the popular video app, which is owned by the Chinese internet company ByteDance.
item.dc:creator: David McCabe and Cecilia Kang
item.category: Committee on Foreign Investment in the United States (CFIUS)
item.media:credit: Ore Huiying for The New York Times
item.media:description: TikTok’s chief executive, Shou Zi Chew, in the ByteDance offices in Singapore. The White House is hardening its stance toward the Chinese-owned video app.

item.title: Your Thursday Briefing: Bank Fears Resurface
item.description: Also, South Korea’s leader visits Japan and Russia gears up for more cyberattacks.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.media:description: Credit Suisse has suffered blow after blow in recent years.

item.title: Sunflower Sea Stars Are Set to Get Protection Under the Endangered Species Act
item.description: Sunflower sea stars, hit by a “climate-fueled pandemic,” play a key role in keeping marine ecosystems balanced.
item.dc:creator: Catrin Einhorn
item.media:description: Sunflower sea stars at the University of Washington laboratory in Friday Harbor. In the wild, they gorge on sea urchins.

item.title: Russia’s Spring Offensive in Ukraine Could Include Cyberattacks, Microsoft Says
item.description: Moscow also appears to be stepping up influence operations to weaken European and U.S. support for sending more aid to the Ukrainian government.
item.dc:creator: Julian E. Barnes, David E. Sanger and Marc Santora
item.media:description: Even as Russian cyberoperations appear poised to intensify, Ukrainian defenses, at least for now, remain strong, according to U.S. and Ukrainian officials.

item.title: Scientists Investigate a Bird Flu Outbreak in Seals
item.description: Wild birds passed the virus to seals in New England at least twice last summer, a new study suggests.
item.dc:creator: Emily Anthes
item.media:description: An usual number of seals were getting stranded and dying off the coast of Maine last summer due to avian influenza.

item.title: When a Military Spies on Citizens’ Phones
item.description: How the Mexican military is using private data against civilians — and what that reveals about the country’s democracy.
item.dc:creator: Lauren Jackson
item.media:credit: Marian Carrasquero for The New York Times
item.media:description: Raymundo Ramos, a human rights advocate in Mexico. With spying tools, the military knows “your personal information, your friendships, everything,” Mr. Ramos said in an interview.

item.title: Tell Us Your Pandemic ‘Silver Lining’
item.description: It has been a traumatic three years. But some good things came out of the upheaval, too.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times

item.title: A YouTuber in Japan Turned His Parliament Post Into a Side Hustle
item.description: The upper house of Japan’s Parliament almost unanimously voted to expel an eccentric YouTuber who won a seat last year. The reason: He never showed up for work.
item.dc:creator: Tiffany May and Hisako Ueno
item.media:description: Japan’s House of Councillors, the upper house of Parliament, voting on Wednesday on whether to expel Yoshikazu Higashitani for not attending any parliamentary sessions since being elected last year.

item.title: U.S. Drone Downed over the Black Sea: What We Know
item.description: The incident was the first known physical contact between the Russian and American militaries since the war in Ukraine began.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Mpoke Bigg
item.media:description: An MQ-9 Reaper drone at Fort Huachuca, Ariz., in November. A Russian warplane struck an American MQ-9 Reaper drone over the Black Sea on Tuesday.

item.title: The U.S. says it won’t stop surveillance flights despite the downing of its drone in the Black Sea.
item.dc:creator: Daniel Victor, Marc Santora, Eric Schmitt and Valerie Hopkins
item.media:description: Anatoly Antonov, center, the Russian ambassador to the United States, after a meeting at the State Department on Tuesday.

item.title: A 1,600-Year-Old Coffin May Shed Light on Roman Britain
item.description: A lead-lined coffin that was discovered in northern England could offer clues about the area’s transition from the Roman Empire to its Anglo-Saxon period.
item.dc:creator: Jenny Gross
item.media:description: Two skeletons that were buried in the same grave at the site.

item.title: Ukraine’s allies are set to discuss the dwindling ammunition supply.
item.dc:creator: Anushka Patil
item.media:credit: Natalie Keyssar for The New York Times
item.media:description: Missile casings under production in Scranton, Pa., in January. Many will be shipped to Ukraine to help replenish dwindling ammunition supplies.

item.title: Putin claims the West is trying to ‘pull apart’ Russia.
item.dc:creator: Ivan Nechepurenko
item.media:description: A member of Ukraine’s 24th Mechanized Brigade in a trench outside Toretsk, in eastern Ukraine, on Saturday.

item.title: Your Wednesday Briefing
item.description: The collision of a U.S. drone and a Russian fighter jet.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: The MQ-9 Reaper drone is a staple of the United States’ military air fleet and is used both for surveillance and for attacks.

item.title: What Do Spring Festivals Look Like in Your Part of Europe?
item.description: We’re asking readers about spring festivals and traditions in their communities.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times

item.title: U.S. Says Russian Fighter Jet Hit American Drone Over Black Sea
item.description: The incident was the first known physical contact between the two militaries since the war in Ukraine began last year.
item.dc:creator: Eric Schmitt
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: The MQ-9 Reaper drone is a staple of the United States’ military air fleet and is used both for surveillance and for attacks.

item.title: True Liberation Eludes Kherson as Russian Shelling Intensifies in Ukraine
item.description: Months after Ukrainian forces pushed out Russian occupiers, the city of Kherson remains very much a war zone.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora and Eric Nagourney
item.media:description: Russia has recently increased its shelling of the city of Kherson, seen this month.

item.title: The Black Sea Is a Crucial Theater in the War Between Russia and Ukraine
item.description: Long dominated by Russia’s navy, the Black Sea has been the scene of Ukrainian defiance. It’s also been a rare point of agreement between the two countries.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Mpoke Bigg
item.media:description: The Black Sea seen from Cape Fiolent, outside the Crimean port city of Sevastopol, in 2018.

item.title: Your Wednesday Briefing: A Downed U.S. Drone
item.description: Also, U.S. markets seem to stabilize and Xi Jinping tightens his control over China’s economy.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: An MQ-9 Reaper drone at a Naval Air Station at Sigonella, Sicily, in 2022. The U.S. European Command said the same model of drone was downed after being intercepted by Russian warplanes over the Black Sea.

item.title: What To Know About the Reaper Drone That Was Downed in the Black Sea
item.description: The unmanned aircraft that was downed in the Black Sea is used both for surveillance and for targeted attacks.
item.dc:creator: Carly Olson
item.media:description: An MQ-9 Reaper drone in November before flying a mission over the U.S.-Mexico border in Arizona.

item.title: Poland Convicts Activist of Aiding an Abortion by Providing Pills
item.description: It was the first conviction of its type in the country and in Europe, offering a glimpse of the implications of a near-total ban on abortion.
item.dc:creator: Monika Pronczuk
item.media:description: Supporters of the rights activist Justyna Wydrzynska awaiting her arrival at court in Warsaw on Tuesday.

item.title: Who Was Leonardo’s Mother? A Novelist Has Evidence She Was Enslaved.
item.description: An author has a theory that the artist’s mother, Caterina, was kidnapped as a girl in the Caucasus area of Central Asia.
item.dc:creator: Elisabetta Povoledo
item.media:description: A news conference about the book “Caterina’s Smile” in Florence, Italy, on Tuesday. It is a historical novel based on evidence about the origins of Leonardo da Vinci’s mother.

item.title: The U.S. Program That Brought H.I.V. Treatment to 20 Million People
item.description: Over two decades, Pepfar may have saved an estimated 25 million lives, helping to slow the AIDS pandemic.
item.dc:creator: Apoorva Mandavilli
item.category: President's Emergency Plan for AIDS Relief
Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
item.media:description: In Uganda, one of the first countries supported by Pepfar, the program has prevented nearly half a million H.I.V. infections since 2004 and saved more than 600,000 lives.

item.title: EPA to Restrict Toxic PFAS Chemicals in Drinking Water
item.description: The government will strictly limit in drinking water two chemicals that are ubiquitous in modern society but are linked to a range of health effects.
item.dc:creator: Lisa Friedman
item.media:credit: Jake May/The Flint Journal, via Associated Press
item.media:description: PFAS, an abbreviation for perfluoroalkyl and polyfluoroalkyl substances, are a class of compounds dubbed “forever chemicals” because they do not break down and persist in the environment, seeping into soil and water.

item.title: An Oil Rush Threatens Natural Splendors Across East Africa
item.description: A multibillion-dollar oil drilling and pipeline project is displacing thousands of people in Uganda and Tanzania, and ravaging pristine habitats. Environmentalists are fighting to stop it, but the governments are all in.
item.dc:creator: Abdi Latif Dahir and Arlette Bashizi
item.media:credit: Arlette Bashizi for The New York Times
item.media:description: African elephants walk near trees in Murchison Falls National Park, northwestern Uganda, in January.

item.title: This Dress Survived for More Than Three Centuries at the Bottom of the Sea
item.description: Divers found an almost perfectly preserved dress in the remains of a ship that sank off the Netherlands in the 1600s. Researchers are trying to figure out who owned the garment.
item.dc:creator: Claire Moses

item.title: Prigozhin, Head of Wagner, Plots Political Advance in Russia
item.description: Yevgeny Prigozhin says his Wagner force will shrink when the battle for the Ukrainian city of Bakhmut is done. Now he’s maneuvering on the home front, for the favor of President Vladimir V. Putin.
item.dc:creator: Anatoly Kurmanaev
item.media:description: Yevgeny Prigozhin, right, the founder of the Wagner private military company, in September at a memorial service for a Wagner fighter in Volgograd, Russia.

item.title: Jiang Yanyong, Who Helped Expose China’s SARS Crisis, Dies at 91
item.description: A retired military surgeon, he blew the whistle in 2003 on Beijing’s cover-up of the epidemic. He was later punished for denouncing the Tiananmen Square crackdown.
item.dc:creator: Amy Qin
item.media:credit: Simon Song/South China Morning Post via Getty Images
item.media:description: Dr. Jiang Yanyong in 2013, 10 years after the SARS outbreak in China. “I was telling the truth,” he said. “I believed the government would treat me fairly.”

item.title: Gary Glitter Is Back in Prison After Violating Probation Terms
item.description: The singer was released from prison last month after serving half of a 16-year sentence for sexually abusing three young girls decades ago.
item.dc:creator: Jenny Gross and Johnny Diaz
item.media:description: Following his release from prison in February, Gary Glitter had been fitted with a GPS tag and faced other restrictions.

item.title: The Bank Failures, Explained
item.description: Officials are worried that a few banks’ collapse is only the beginning.
item.dc:creator: German Lopez
item.media:description: Silicon Valley Bank in Santa Clara, Calif.

item.title: Flood of Russians Alters Life for Countries That Took Them In
item.description: Russians, fleeing their country and its war, have quickly reshaped the societies of nations like Georgia and Armenia.
item.dc:creator: Sergey Ponomarev and Ivan Nechepurenko
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times

item.title: Macron Faces Pivotal Week in His Attempt to Change France at Its Core
item.description: Huge crowds are again expected to protest President Emmanuel Macron’s plan to raise the retirement age before a decisive vote that could redefine his nation and his legacy.
item.dc:creator: Roger Cohen
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Emmanuel Macron of France, shown in April in Paris, has been met with huge street protests over his plan to raise the legal age of retirement to 64 from 62.

item.title: Russian Attacks Along a Wide Arc of Ukraine Yield Little but Casualties
item.description: Moscow’s forces have stepped up artillery and infantry assaults across eastern Ukraine, trying to improve their position before either side attempts a major breakthrough.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora, Matthew Mpoke Bigg and Richard Pérez-Peña
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:description: A Ukrainian soldier in a trench outside Toretsk in Donetsk Province on Saturday. Russian forces are attacking along a 160-mile arc in eastern Ukraine in an intensifying struggle for tactical advantage.

item.title: Biden Extends Stay for Thousands of Ukrainians
item.description: One-year extensions for those who fled in the first months after Russia’s invasion will be granted on a case-by-case basis, officials said.
item.dc:creator: Eileen Sullivan
item.media:credit: Mark Abramson for The New York Times
item.media:description: Migrants from Ukraine waited at the U.S.-Mexico border in 2022, before being allowed to enter the United States.

item.title: Your Tuesday Briefing: A U.S. Banking Crisis
item.description: Also, Russia is set to face war crimes charges and China’s new premier seeks to reassure investors.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.media:description: Clients stood in line outside Silicon Valley Bank waiting to enter in Santa Clara, Cali., on Monday.

item.title: 10 Years On, Pope Francis Faces Challenges From the Right and the Left
item.description: In an ideologically divided Roman Catholic Church, the right has accused him of going too far and the left of not going far enough.
item.dc:creator: Jason Horowitz
item.category: Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships
item.media:description: Many of the faithful are wondering whether Pope Francis will make concrete and transformative change or decide once and for all that such shifts will not happen.

item.title: A Mossad Agent’s Treasure Trove of Photos
item.description: Sylvia Rafael worked undercover as a news agency photographer. Her pictures for the Israeli spy agency sat in its archives for decades before being released for a show.
item.dc:creator: Ronen Bergman
item.media:description: Sylvia Rafael, a photographer and Mossad agent, in Yemen in 1967.

item.title: Cyclone Freddy Persists, Leaving Scores More Dead in Africa
item.description: A storm that has broken records for its longevity — now 35 days — swept inland from the southeastern coast of Africa and is causing massive flooding and displacement.
item.dc:creator: Golden Matonga and Lynsey Chutel
item.media:description: Searching for victims of Cyclone Freddy in Blantyre, Malawi, on Monday.
